The worst case scenario (WCS) was a vapor cloud explosion from an instantaneous release of the total contents of a single, recovered butane storage tank containing 60,000 gallons of butane.  Although there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, should prevent or mitigate the release, no credit for mitigation measures was taken into account for this scenario. The alternate release scenario (ARS) was a boiling liquid expanding vapor explosion (BLEVE) of a single, recovered butane storage tank containing 60,000 gallons of butane.  Although there are numerous installed control measures that, in an actual event, should prevent or mitigate the release, no credit for mitigation measures was taken into account for this scenario.  The endpoint distance results for this WCS were generated by EPAs RMP*Comp program. 1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention, Emergency Response, and Commitment to EHS at the Ironton PCT Site
The Pure Cycles Ironton site is part of PureCycle Technologies, Inc. (PCT).  PCTs mission is to revolutionize plastic waste into a renewable resource and to do so by operating in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.  PCT is committed to being a responsible member of any community in which it operates.  Achieving consistently high production in manufacturing is not a goal, it is an outcome of the pursuit of safe and reliable operations.  Goal Zero is the name of the safety culture PureCycle has adopted at the Ironton site to drive safe, reliable, and environmentally responsible operations. Goal Zero is about keeping people, the surrounding community, and the environment safe, always.  PCTs Goal Zero culture can be summarizes via the 3 elements listed below:
1. A commitment to always follow the rules.
2. A belief that it is possible to work incident free every day. 
3. A requirement to report and learn from all incidents.
PCTs commitment to safe and environmentally sound operations is documented within the Goal Zero program.  All PCT Team Members are trained on the Goal Zero safety culture to ensure accountability and commitment throughout all levels of the PCT organization. 
PCTs Goal Zero safety culture extends throughout the Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Program for the Ironton PCT site.  As part of the Goal Zero safety culture, PCT affirms to employees, customers, and the community to conduct business with respect and care for the environment.  As part of Goal Zero, PCT believes that all safety and environmental incidents are preventable with the goal of zero incidents.  The safety, health, and environmental impact of any proposed modification at any PCT site will be assessed to ensure that the site continues to operate in a safe and environmentally responsible manner.  In addition, all PCT sites will be

prepared for emergencies to ensure that in the unlikely event of an accidental release, employees and visitors at the site as well as the surrounding community are unharmed and the environment is protected.  Through the Accidental Release Prevention program as documented within this report and each PCT sites Emergency Preparedness and Response procedure (referenced within this report), PCT aims to promote open discussion with employees, visitors, customers, and the community with respect to process operations, including raw materials used and how PCT products are made, and the impacts of such activities on safety, health, and the environment.

1.2 Description of the Ironton Site, Site Processes, and Prioritization of EHS

1.2.1 Description of the Physical Site
The Ironton PCT Site is located at 1125 County Road 1A (CR 1A) in Ironton, Lawrence County, Ohio.  It is located approximately 100 miles south of Columbus, Ohio near the Ohio River across from the State of Kentucky.
The Ironton PCT site consists of approximately 26 acres of land, which is a portion of a former Dow Chemical foam extrusion plant.  This site includes three existing buildings that PCT reused.  
An active Norfolk Southern Corporation (NSC) railroad mainline forms the northern boundary of this site.  To the south, the Ironton PCT site extends to the boundary of the wooded area around 38.575º latitude.  
The Ironton PCT site is comprised of generally level terrain. Per FEMA Flood Insurance Rate Map 39087C0208D, this site is in Flood Zone X, an area outside the 100-year floodplain within an area of 0.2 percent annual chance of flood hazard. 
Highway access to the Ironton PCT site is convenient over national highways, state routes and county roads.  Access to this site will be from U.S. Route 52 via existing access road from CR 1A.  Rail access is serviced by NSC.  The NSC mainline abuts the northern boundary of the site and a new eastern rail spur will facilitate transport of finished product.

1.2.2 Description of Site Processes and Stationary Source
Commercial operations at the Ironton PCT site make use of a new, advanced recycling technology taking scrap polypropylene (plastic #5) and recycling it into an ultra-pure recycled plastic.  This process eliminates odors, color, and contaminants from plastic via the following stages:
	Melting & Filtration
	Extraction
	Mixing & Settling
	Filtration
	Purification
	Separation
	Extrusion & Pelletization
In simple terms, PCT collects and prepares waste plastic as a raw material, purifies the recycled plastic material, and produces pellets of plastic that can be reused repeatedly without compromise to the end user.
The key benefits of PCTs commercial scale operations at the Ironton site are the following:
	All unit operations are well-known and commercially available.
	PCT utilizes a solvent-based purification process in which there are no chemical reactions.
	Process operating conditions are comparable to current polyolefin (polypropylene and polyethylene) production conditions.
The solvent used in PCTs commercial process is near critical and supercritical butane.  Butane is used throughout commercial operations at the Ironton site as evident in the process flow diagram above.  Butane is flammable.  As commercial process operations at the Ironton site contain > 10,000 pounds of butane in storage and in the interconnected process, the commercial process at the Ironton site is covered by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  The characteristics and hazards of butane are described on the following page.

1.2.3 Characteristics and Hazards of Supercritical Butane and Safeguards Applied
Supercritical fluids are those that exist at pressures and temperatures that exceed the critical pressure and critical temperature.  In the supercritical state, fluids are compressible.  Close to the critical point, the fluid density (and hence solubility parameter) and tr

ansport properties (diffusivity and viscosity) can be dramatically varied from gas-like to liquid-like values by relatively small variations in pressure and/or temperature.  Near critical and supercritical butane is used as the solvent in PCTs commercial process.
Butane is a highly flammable, colorless, easily liquefied gas that vaporizes at room temperature.  Butane in air has a very low Minimum Ignition Energy (MIE).  When flammable mixtures, such as butane vapor in air at certain concentrations, locate an ignition source, fire can occur.  As such, unintended butane releases at the Ironton PCT site have the potential to result in fire which can subsequently lead to personnel injury and environmental impact.
To minimize the potential for leaks of butane at PCTs Ironton site, inherently safe design, pressure relief systems, Basic Process Control System (BPCS) interlocks, Safety Instrumented System (SIS) interlocks, administrative controls, and extensive operator training have been included.  To minimize the potential for fire should butane leakage occur, flammable gas detectors have been located throughout process operations at Ironton.  These flammable gas detectors have been equipped with alarms that will alert the control room as well as local audible and visual alarms set at 10% of the lower explosive limit (LEL) to provide notification well before any release reaches the flammable/explosive range.  In addition, where necessary, interlocks have been added to automatically take the process to a safe state should 40% of the LEL be reached.  Finally, flame detectors (fire-eyes), sprinklers, and automatic deluge systems have been located throughout process operations to prevent catastrophic consequences.

1.3.2 Process Hazard Analysis
The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) including Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) Standard, COR-PSM-STN-0030 [2], establishes the program for assessing the hazards of covered process operations at the Ironton Site.  By systematically examining each covered process and identifying the hazards associated with operation of the process, the Ironton site has been able to plan for

and will take appropriate actions to improve the safety of our employees, contractors, and visitors, the community, and the environment.
PHAs and LOPAs have been conducted for all process operations at the Ironton facility covered by standard COR-PSM-STN-0030 [2].  PHAs/LOPAs are conducted in a manner appropriate to the complexity of the process.  The objectives of the PHAs/LOPAs are the following:
	To identify the hazards of the process
	To identify credible human error and/or equipment failures that could lead to accidental release
	To evaluate the likelihood and severity of potential scenarios
	To determine if existing safeguards (engineering and/or administrative controls) are adequate
	Where existing safeguards are inadequate, identify additional safeguards that should be considered 

Per OSHA/EPA PSM/RMP requirements, all initial PHAs/LOPAs will be conducted prior to facility startup and will be revalidated every 5 years.  In addition, to the extent possible, scheduling priority of future revalidation PHAs/LOPAs should be based on the extent of the process hazards, number of potentially affected employees, and age and operating history for the involved units.
When a PHA/LOPA team identifies a scenario for which existing safeguards are not adequate, an action item(s), also known as recommendation(s), to prevent, detect, or mitigate the scenario to reduce the risk to an acceptable level will be generated and assigned to the appropriate Team Member or Department.  In the context of PHAs/LOPAs recommendations are synonymous with action items.  All PHA/LOPA recommendations will be addressed and tracked to closure.

1.3.2.1 PHA and LOPA Methodology
General
Initial PHAs and LOPAs for the Ironton facility were conducted using a mixture of What-If, Checklist, What-If/Checklist, and Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodologies to determine and evaluate the hazards of the covered processes.  Future PHAs and LOPAs will also utilize acceptable PHA methodologi

es which include the following:
	What-If
	Checklist
	What-If/Checklist
	Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP)
	Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA)
	Fault Tree Analysis
The PHA and LOPA methodology used shall be appropriate for the complexity of the process. Typically, for new projects HAZOP or What-If PHA methodology is appropriate.  For PHAs conducted as part of the MOC process, typically What If, Checklist, or What-If/Checklist PHA methodology is appropriate.  The Process Safety Program Manager can provide guidance on appropriate PHA methodology as needed.
All PHAs will address the following:
	The hazards of the process.
	Any previous incident with potential for catastrophic consequences in the workplace.
	Engineering/administrative controls related to hazards.
	Consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls.
	Facility siting (the location of various components within the facility).
	Human factors.
	Qualitative evaluation of possible safety/health effects on employees stemming from control failures.
PHAs for MOCs (Management of Change) and Incident Investigation Follow-Up
When a change is made to a facility there can be safety and/or environmental ramifications.  Accordingly, it is often necessary to conduct a PHA as part of the MOC process.  
If an incident occurs, it is possible that a potential hazard scenario was not identified during the initial or revalidated PHA or that a safeguard listed in the existing PHA was not effective.  Accordingly, it is often necessary to conduct a PHA as follow-up to an Incident Investigation.
For PHAs at the Ironton site that are conducted as part of MOC or as follow-up to an Incident Investigation, the existing PHA will be revised as needed or a new PHA using What If, Checklist, or What-If/Checklist methodology will be created to evaluate safety and environmental impacts.  If the item under consideration is part of a PSM covered process, the resulting PHA sessions shall become part of the ex

isting PHA record with the MOC or Incident Investigation PHA being revalidated at the next 5-year revalidation interval.    To ensure that revalidation of MOC and Incident Investigation PHAs associated with PSM covered processes takes place, if a separate What If PHA is conducted for the MOC or Incident Investigation follow-up, the resultant PHA will be stored in the same folder as the latest PHA and a reminder to revalidate all MOC and Incident Investigation PHAs will be included in the PHA Review List provided as Appendix A of COR-PSM-STN-00300, Process Hazard Analysis including LOPA Standard [2].
Revalidation Schedule
The Site EHS Manager shall create and maintain an up-to-date PHA Revalidation Schedule for the Ironton site that contains the following information:
	Title of the PHA.
	Brief description of the scope of the PHA.
	Whether the PHA is covered under OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP.
	Date the previous PHA started.
	Date the previous PHA was completed.
	Proposed start date for the next PHA revalidation.
	An estimate of the hours needed to complete the next PHA revalidation.
With respect to the date the next PHA revalidation must be completed, if the PHA is covered under OSHA PSM and/or EPA RMP, this date must not be greater than 5 years from the date that the previous PHA was completed.  (OSHA PSM and EPA RMP require that PHAs for covered processes be revalidated at minimum every 5 years.)

1.3.2.2 PHA Team 
PHAs shall be performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, and the team shall include at least one employee who has experience and knowledge specific to the process being evaluated.
PHAs shall include one member of the team that is knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology being used.
PHA Core Team Members shall include: 
	The Operations Manager or designee.
	The Director of Engineering or designee.
	A Process Controls and Instrumentation Representative.  (This role may be fulfilled by the Director of Engineering o

r designee.)
	A qualified Operator or Supervisor that is knowledgeable and familiar with the process that is being evaluated.
	The Site EHS Manager or designee trained and knowledgeable in the PHA methodology that is being utilized.  (This role may be fulfilled by the Process Safety Program Manager, by the Director of EHS, or an external consultant.)
If any of the above named PHA Team Members is not available, the assigned Team Member may provide a deputy or other qualified designee to take their place.
PHA Auxiliary Team Members who may be called upon on an as needed basis include:
	Specific Subject Matter Expert (SME)  e.g., an external vendor who is an SME on the technology or the equipment under review
	Asset Integrity Maintenance and Reliability (AIM&R) Program Manager
	Maintenance Representative
	Occupational Health, Safety & Security (OHSS) Program Manager 
	Environmental Compliance & Sustainability (EC&S) Program Manager
As a best practice, it is recommended that PHA Teams use a designated scribe to document PHAs.  A designated PHA scribe is someone that: 
	Is familiar with the PHA methodology being used.
	Is familiar with the documentation method.
	Is typically not the Project Manager or the MOC Owner.
	Is willing to capture the results in sufficient detail such that the analysis is clear to readers who are not present during the PHA discussions.
Any Team Members assigned the role of PHA scribe will be provided additional training to support the needed competencies.

1.3.3 Operating Procedure
Current, clearly written standard operating procedures and safe work practices help both experienced and inexperienced employees (including contract employees) respond in a safe, consistent, and prescribed manner. Operating Procedures Standard, COR-TRG-STN-0002 [3], specifies that written procedures/practices are developed, reviewed, implemented, and annually certified as reflective of current plant practice.
The procedure requires that operating procedures

shall:
	Ensure all operating procedures are stored in the ATR SmartProcedure Platform. 
	Ensure each operating procedure has an owner, typically the Operations Manager. 
	Ensure the system of access for procedures is readily accessible to affected Team Members, i.e., to Team Members who work in or maintain a process.
	Ensure operating procedures are utilized each time the document is applicable unless indicated otherwise within the document. 
	Utilize the built-in workflow in ATR SmartProcedures to manage changes to procedures.
Elements within operating procedures include: 
	Environmental, Health, and Safety (EHS) considerations: 
o	Hazard information from or references to applicable Safety Data Sheets (SDS). 
o	Properties of, and hazards presented by, the chemicals used in the process. 
o	PPE, engineering controls, administrative controls in place to prevent exposure. 
o	Control measures to be taken if exposure occurs. 
o	Descriptions of operational requirements necessary for the management of storm water, wastewater, air emissions, spills, waste, or any other environmental aspects potentially impacted by the execution of the procedure.  These requirements would be specific to the tasks covered in each procedure and are not intended to be used in lieu of site-wide environmental procedures or requirements. 
o	Any special or unique hazards.
	Safety Systems and their functions: 
o	Critical / Emergency alarms and their set points including a description of corrective actions and consequences of remaining in alarm. 
o	Safety interlocks descriptions including trip points and interlock actions.
o	External detection and suppression systems descriptions for fire and releases of flammables.  
	Safe Operating Limits including: 
o	Acceptable operating ranges and safety limits. 
o	A table of consequences of deviation from safe operating limits on critical variables, guidance on potential causes, and steps to correct or avoid the deviation.   
	Steps for the following

operating phases, as applicable: 
o	Initial Startup 
o	Normal Operations 
o	Normal Shutdown 
o	Temporary Operations 
o	Emergency Operations should include the conditions that trigger a transition from normal operations to emergency operations.  An example would be sudden, but not complete, loss of a critical utility like steam. 
o	Emergency Shutdown should include the conditions that trigger an emergency shutdown and the assignment of shutdown responsibilities to ensure that emergency shutdown is executed in a safe and timely manner. 
o	Startup following an extended outage (turnaround) or emergency shutdown. 
All operating procedures shall be reviewed by someone certified in the process annually, or more frequently if required by local regulatory requirements, to ensure current operating practices are properly reflected. This annual review shall be documented within ATR SmartProcedures including the date of the review and who completed the review. At least one reviewer must be a Team Member required to use the procedure.

1.3.4 Training 
The intent of PCTs training program is to help employees understand the nature and causes of problems arising from process and facility operations and increase employee awareness with respect to the hazards particular to a process or facility. Employee Training Standard, COR-TRG-STN-0001 [4], defines how PCT trains personnel with respect to operating and maintaining processes. 
The Employee Training Standard, COR-TRG-STN-0001 [4], specifies, per OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard in 29 CFR 1910.119 Paragraph (g) and EPAs Risk Management Plant Rule in 40 CFR Part 68.71, that each employee involved in operating a PSM or RMP covered process must be trained in an overview of the process and in its operating procedures, receive refresher training at least every three years, and that such training will be appropriately documented.  Furthermore, the Employee Training Standard, COR-TRG-STN-0001 [4], specifies per OSHAs PSM S

tandard in 29 CFR 1910.119 Paragraph (j) and EPAs RMP Rule in 40 CFR Part 68.73, that employees involved in maintaining the ongoing integrity of process equipment in a PSM or RMP covered process must be trained in an overview of the process and its hazards and trained in the procedures applicable to the employees job tasks.
PCTs training program satisfies the requirements of OSHAs PSM standard and EPAs RMP rule and is comprised of the following: 
	Initial training
	Refresher training
	Process overview training
	Training provided as a result of management of change (MOC)
	Verification of understanding
	Training documentation
All operators receive initial training in safe work practices and basic operating principles prior to assignment.  Operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process.  Training assignments are determined by Department Heads (such as an Operations Manager or Maintenance Manager) and shall be conveyed to the Technical Training Manager for incorporation into the Training Matrix. Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training.  Documentation of training is maintained by the Training Department.  The Training Department maintains a training matrix of all initial and refresher training.  The eMOC system is used to maintain records of training conducted as part of MOCs.  Refresher training on the Training Standard itself shall be provided when conditions warrant, such as a major revision or if there are indications that Training Standard COR-TRG-STN-001 [4] is not being adequately followed.

1.3.5 Mechanical Integrity
PCT manages Mechanical Integrity following the Mechanical Integrity Risk Based Inspection Standard, COR-REL-ST-0010 [5] and Asset Integrity Standard, COR-REL-ST-0001 [6]. 
The purpose of the Mechanical Integrity (MI) Risk Based Inspection (RBI) Program Standard [5] is to provide a summary and refe

rence guide for PCTs MI RBI Program. The MI RBI program will track and mitigate risk for stationary process assets throughout PCT global facilities including those at the Ironton site.  The MI RBI Standard specifies the scope of the MI RBI program, responsibilities for personnel, and MI RBI program requirements including Quantitative Inspection Tables. 
The purpose of the Asset Integrity (AI) Standard, COR-REL-ST-0001 [6] is to describe the Asset Integrity Program for effective execution of Workflow, Reliability, Mechanical Integrity and Turnaround processes.  A variety of software and hardware will facilitate the work processes and data management described therein.  Following this program will provide for safe, reliable, and low-cost operation of rotating, stationary and electrical assets while maximizing asset life expectancy and productivity. The AI Standard specifies the scope of the AI program, responsibilities for personnel, and AI program requirements.
The AI Standard [6] is used in conjunction with the MI RBI Standard [5] to manage Mechanical Integrity at the Ironton facility. 

1.3.6 Management of Change
PCT manages change following the Management of Change (MOC) Standard, COR-PSM-ST-0100 [7]. This standard is to ensure that changes to PCTs processes, other than Replacements-In-Kind (RIK), are made safely and in an environmentally responsible manner and are communicated to all affected personnel. This standard establishes how to initiate and implement changes to processes and the requirements therein.
PCT utilizes an electronic MOC program (referred to as eMOC) to manage changes efficiently.  The eMOC system is the tool for implementation of the MOC standard.  Where necessary, the standard includes  verbiage regarding eMOC.
Changes to processes subject to this standard require documented review and authorization prior to implementation.
The MOC standard specifies changes that are subject to the standard, which includes, but not limited to, changes to pro

cesses, equipment, PSI, chemicals, quality, environmental aspects, and the organization.

1.3.7 Pre-Start Up Safety Review (PSSR)
A Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) is a structured team effort in which personnel with various technical backgrounds review the status and condition of a process to ensure the process is safe to startup. PCT performs Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSR) at the Ironton site following the Pre-Startup Safety Review Standard, COR-PSM-STN-0070 [8], which establishes a means to verify that new or modified chemical and/or mechanical process operations at PCT facilities are safe for startup prior to the introduction of hazardous energy and/or chemicals. 
The scope of the standard includes PSSRs for greenfield facilities and new capital projects, for modifications documented as part of the MOC program, and for startups after turnaround and maintenance outages.  Conducting PSSRs minimizes the likelihood of safety or environmental impacts during and even after startups regardless of whether the process is covered by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard or EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  As such, this standard is applicable to both polypropylene purification and pre-processing (PreP) facilities at the Ironton site.  It is not applicable to corporate or other administrative offices and business-related changes.
The standard provides information about personnel responsibilities associated with PSSR and requirements for the PSSR, which include: 
	Appropriate PSSR Team Members
	PSSRs for Greenfield Sites/Facilities and New Capital Projects
	PSSRs for MOCs 
	PSSRs for Turnarounds and Maintenance Outages
	Preparing for a PSSR
	Conducting a PSSR
	PSSR Action Item Resolution and Tracking
	PSSR Closeout
	PSSR Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Auditing
	Training

1.3.8 Compliance Audit
PCT ensures that the prevention program elements are functioning properly, complete, current, and applied in compliance with company policy, regula

tions, and good process safety practices as these are vital to the continuous improvement of the prevention program.  PCTs Operational Excellence (OE) Management System Effectiveness Verification Standard, COR-OE-STN-0001 [9] establishes the minimum requirements necessary to establish the ongoing effectiveness of applicable components of the Operational Excellence Management System via auditing.
This standard ensures the applicable components of the Operational Excellence Management System are functioning as intended at all manufacturing locations, including the Ironton site, to outline the process for auditing each location, and to document the process for assessing and closing any gaps.  In addition, each element of PCTs PSM/RMP Program will be audited every 3 years to ensure that requirements of OSHAs PSM Standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and EPAs RMP Program (40 CFR 68) are being met.  
Responsible managers must certify that they have evaluated their compliance with the provisions of OSHA PSM (29 CFR § 1910.119) and EPA RMP (40 CFR Part 68) to verify that the procedures and practices that have been developed are adequate and are being followed.  PCT will maintain copies of the last two audits on file.
1.3.9 Incident Investigation
PCTs Incident Reporting and Investigation Standard, COR-SAF-ST-0006 [10], establishes the requirements for reporting work related incidents and investigation of the incidents at PCT sites. Incidents may include, but are not limited to, injuries, illnesses, spills, releases, property or equipment damage, near misses, and security incidents involving personnel or property.
The Incident Reporting and Investigation Standard defines the requirements for: 
	Initial Incident Reporting
	Initial Actions
	Incident Documentation and Follow-Up
	Incident Investigation
	Root Cause Analysis Evaluation
	Action Item Due Dates and Deadlines
The Incident Reporting and Investigation Standard also provides guidance for: 
	Guidelines for Incident Report

ing and Investigation 
	Recommended Timeline for Completing the Investigation Report 
	Incident Report Process Flow 
	Incidents and Sub-Incidents Categories 
	Root Cause Analysis (RCA) Techniques
	Guidelines for Managing Human Factors RCA
Intelex is the electronic tool that is used to document incidents and subsequent investigations.
1.3.10 Employee Participation
PCTs Employee Participation Standard, COR-PSM-ST-0010 [11], establishes the Employee Participation (EP) program as required by OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPAs Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.  This standard describes how PCT employees, including those at the Ironton site, participate in each of the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP elements.  The EP program defined in this standard is intended to provide an environment that encourages the flow of information between management to employees and between employees to management to eliminate or mitigate the consequences of catastrophic releases of highly hazardous chemicals in the workplace.  Specifically, the purpose of EP is to involve employees in the development of the PSM program and to ensure that all affected employees have access to the information developed under the PSM program to improve process safety throughout PCT.
In addition to committees, teams, and functions specifically established to address process safety issues, other plant activities offer employees the opportunity to participate in and relay concerns about process safety, including: 
	Training sessions
	Regularly scheduled safety meetings
	Periodic departmental EHS and PSM audits
	Safe Work Permits
	Site Safety Committee meetings
	Roundtable meetings
	Toolbox talks
	PHA and Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) sessions

1.3.11 Hot Work Permit
Controlling ignition sources is vital to Irontons release prevention program.  It is critical that applicable personnel are notified when hot work is to be performed at the Ironton site and that appropriate safety precauti

ons are taken prior to initiation of hot work. PCTs Hot Work Program Standard, COR-SAF-PRG-0015 [12], establishes requirements for a safe hot work program, as required by OSHA 29CFR 1910.252, Welding, Cutting and Brazing; 29 CFR 1910.119 (k), Hot Work Permit; 29CFR1926.352, Fire Prevention, Welding and Cutting; and NFPA 51B, Standard for Fire Prevention During Welding, Cutting, and Other Hot Work. These requirements include the development of written procedures to prevent fires resulting from any temporary operation involving open flames or producing heat and/or sparks.  Hot Work activities include, but are not limited to welding, burning, grinding, chipping, brazing, soldering, thawing pipes, sand blasting, metal-on-metal contact or metal-on-concrete, internal combustion engines and other potentially spark producing equipment or activities, including static electrical discharges.  A Hot Work Permit is required when such work is identified as a hazard such as when this work is to be performed outside of designated hot work areas and is always required for hot work in classified areas at the Ironton site including for operation of non-rated mobile equipment, power tools, spark or heat producing tools/equipment, and the use of battery powered devices.  All permitted hot work requires continuous atmospheric monitoring, removal or protection of flammable/combustible materials and immediate availability of an appropriate fire extinguisher.

1.3.12 Contractors
PCTs Contractor Safety Management Standard (CSMS), COR-SAF-ST-0021 [13], has been put in place to prevent injuries and illness as well as other safety and environmental incidents due to the activities of contractors working for PCT. The CSMS establishes minimum criteria for contractor Environmental, Health, Safety and Security (EHSS) management and provides guidance to Team Members who manage contractors to ensure safe completion of contracted work.
This standard applies to contractors performing work or seeking a

pproval to perform work for PCT.  Vendors and other companies providing incidental services that do not influence processes or process equipment safety such as printer supply and servicing, vending machine supply and servicing, etc. are exempted from most of the requirements of this standard, except for orientation.  Delivery and pick-up companies (e.g., UPS, FedEx, DHS, etc.) that provide delivery and pick-up services to a PCT owned or leased site are not included in the scope of this contractor standard.
The five principal phases of the CSMS life cycle include: 
	Prequalification (Contract Management, Safety, Procurement, Environmental)
	Pre-Job Work Plan & Risk Assessment (Contract Management, Safety, Procurement, Environmental)
	Contractor Training & Orientations (Contract Management)
	Monitoring of Work Execution (Contract Management, Safety, Environmental)
	Post-Job Evaluations (Contract Management, Safety, Environmental, Procurement)
The groups that are involved in the principal phases are given in parentheses next to the phase above.

1.4 Five-Year Accident History
The Commercial Plant that is being constructed at the Ironton site is a new installation. As such there is no five-year accident history.  There is a Feed Evaluation Unit (FEU) that already exists at the Ironton site.  The FEU is not part of the PSM and RMP covered process as it is not and will not be interconnected to the Commercial Plant and also does not have the threshold quantity of butane requiring PSM or RMP coverage.  Note however that there have not been any accidental releases from the FEU that resulted in deaths, injuries, property damage, or environmental impact either onsite or offsite since FEU operations commenced.

1.5 Emergency Response Program
Overall safety at the Ironton site is governed not only by the ability to prevent accidental releases, but also by the ability to mitigate any accidental releases.  PCTs Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan and Hazardous Waste Con

tingency Plan for the Ironton site, IRO-SAF-PRC-3000 [14], establishes policies and procedures and an organizational hierarchy for response to emergencies, including those involving releases of flammable liquids and gases as well as hazardous waste, occurring at the PCT Ironton, Ohio location. This site level Emergency Plan guides the response of PCT Team Members and resources during an emergency, establishes requirements to effectively prepare for all identified credible emergency scenarios, and provides guidance for post emergency recovery. This is the official Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan for the Ironton facility and supersedes previous plans and is intended to prevent Team Member actions which are not in accordance with the intent of this plan.
The Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan and Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan applies to all Ironton site Team Members, contractors, and visitors.  Every PCT Ironton Team Member is expected to adhere to the requirements of this plan.  Managers and Supervisors have a special obligation to keep informed about the health, safety, and environmental risks associated with production, handling and distribution of products, raw materials, and intermediates, and hazardous waste(s); and to advise higher management promptly of any adverse situation.
With respect to fires, the Ironton site does not have a fire brigade and is therefore dependent upon the local Fire Department for response to fires that escalate beyond incipient phase.  Properly trained employees can respond to incipient fires requiring one fire extinguisher after notifying the local Fire Department.  The Ironton site will work closely with the local Fire Department to prevent fires from occurring and to quickly mitigate fires should they occur.  As specified in IRO-SAF-PRC-3000 [14], fire extinguisher training for response to incipient fires will be provided to Team Members.  In addition, the local Fire Department will be called upon to perform walk-th

roughs of the process such that they are familiar with the Ironton site before there is a need to respond to an emergency.  This pre-planning will ensure that Team Members at the Ironton site are aware of the preferred method of notifying the local Fire Department (e.g., activation of any of the manual pull switches, deluge, or sprinkler system automatically sounds an audible alarm and alerts the local Fire Department).  This pre-planning also ensures that members of the local Fire Department are familiar with the stationary source, the hazards of butane, the resources available at the stationary source, and the locations of site resources that can be used to address a fire.
The Ironton site has developed the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan within IRO-SAF-PRC-3000 [4] to respond to releases of butane and other emergencies.  The Ironton site maintains emergency response equipment and personal protective equipment (PPE) for use by Team Members responding to emergencies and members of the local Fire Department.  The emergency response equipment is included in the mechanical integrity program and requires testing, inspection, and preventive maintenance as per RAGAGEP (recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices).  An annual emergency drill will be held at the Ironton site with participation from offsite responding agencies such as the local Fire Department and PCT Team Members to work together to resolve a given scenario (e.g., release of butane).  This pre-planning activity also ensures that members of the responding agency(ies) are familiar with butane storage and usage at the Ironton site, the hazards of butane, the resources available at the stationary source, and the locations of site resources that can be used to address such an emergency situation.  Such exercises also clearly identify the capabilities and limitations of the responding agency(ies).  Copies of the drill records, including recommendations and critiques, are review and main

tained by PCT with any deficiencies addressed in a timely manner. 
The intentions of the Ironton emergency plan are, in order of importance: 
	To evacuate and account for all personnel on site 
	To contact local emergency service organizations as needed
	To assemble PureCycles Emergency Action Team for implementation of the response plan 
	To conduct search-and-rescue operations, turn off utilities, control any hazardous chemical spills or releases, including hazardous waste spills or releases 
	To contact pertinent regulatory agencies should release occur
	To prevent or mitigate property damage through protective measures or by removing property during an emergency situation
	To perform cleanup, salvage, and decontamination as needed 
	To conduct post-incident critique and evaluation 
	To file applicable reports with regulatory agencies
The Ironton Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan, IRO-SAF-PRC-3000, will be reviewed annually to ensure that it remains accurate and current.  PCT Team Members are trained on the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan when initially hired, when the plan is revised, and when the Team Members responsibilities are changed.  All PCT Team Members will receive annual refresher training on the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan.  In addition, contractors are trained on the Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan such that they understand alarms providing notification of potential emergency situations, how to appropriately respond to such situations, evacuation routes, and muster site locations.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Studies associated with prevention program elements such as PHAs, incident investigation, management of change, and compliance audits are regularly conducted at the Ironton Site to verify designs and to identify potential hazards.  Recommendations may be developed as a result of these studies and as a result of equipment inspections, safety meetings, review of industry experience, techno

logy improvements, and employee suggestions.  Once formulated, recommendations are reviewed, and corresponding action items are developed. All actions are tracked and routinely reviewed by senior management.
